taxonAuthor: Valentich- Scott, Griffiths, Landschoff, Li R, Li J, 2024.

texts.shortText:
Tiny white bivalve with thin, almost completely transparent and fragile oval shell, through which the gills and other body organs can clearly be seen. Most easily identified by its obligate association with the Smooth heart urchin Spatagobrissus mirabilis.

When alive the transparent mantle extends externally to cover much of the shell and is produced forwards into a large tubular inhalant siphon and posteriorly into a smaller exhalent one. The foot is elongate and mobile and is used to actively move around on the host and wrap around and grip onto its spines.
Very small, shell length typically only about 2 mm.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Only very recently discovered and currently known only from a single site in False Bay, but likely much more widely distributed, as the host urchin ranges between southern Namibia and Cape Agulhas.

Only very recently discovered by the Sea Change Project team during examination of heart urchins Spatagobrissus mirabilis in False Bay. The urchins live in shallow burrows in course sand and large numbers of these tiny transparent bivalves can be associated with each urchin. The bivalves move around freely among the urchin spines, using the elongate foot to both locomote and to grip onto individual urchin spines.

The same heart urchins also hosted numerous small amphipods of the family Lysianassidae and larger scale worms of the family Polynoidae (Malmgreniella sp.) and both of these species also appear to be undescribed obligate commensals.

Very little is known about the feeding biology of this species, but almost all bivalves are filter feeders, sucking in seawater and removing fine particulate material from it by passing the water though their enlarged sieve-like gills. The urchins probably simply act as a convenient solid substratum onto which the bivalves can attach.

All members of this family are hermaphroditic and lack a larval stage. Instead, they brood their young, protecting them among their gills, and releasing them when fully developed onto the surface of the sea urchin occupies by the parent. Reproduction in this species has not been studied in any detail, but up to 10 shelled juveniles have been observed attached to the gills of mature specimens.

Many species in this family have symbiotic associations with other larger invertebrates, including urchins. Although numerous other galeommatid species have been described from South Africa this is the only one currently known to be associated with urchins.

Valentich-Scott, P, Griffiths, C, Landschoff, J, Li, R & Li, J (2024). Bivalves of superfamily Galeommatoidea (Mollusca, Bivalvia) from western South Africa, with observations on commensal relationships and habitats. ZooKeys, 1207, 301-323.
